Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: Financial modeling
Better skills at reading contracts and to make models in Excel

Prior to taking this course, I had no knowledge on finance.  I now have a good understanding of basic financial concepts and how to apply them to clean energy development.  I also gained a ton of skills in excel and now feel very confident in my excel modeling.
Learned financial modeling, the specifics of wind power, and about the greater landscape of project finance.
Project finance; excel modeling techniques; intro to contracts and transaction structuring; background on and state of of renewable energy development (particularly in the US)
All around financial models in the renewable energy sector with some technical background.
Excel, contract analysis, financial concepts.
Modelling in excel, project finance from different perspectives, reading legal documents.
Project finance, financial modeling, Excel best practice, renewable energy policy, business development, interactions with clean tech finance professionals
Financial modeling and a lot of knowledge about finance.
Learned really useful tools for financial modeling such as Debt sizing, payment scheduling, sensitivity analysis LCOE calculations, risks associated with project management etc.

Financial modeling 
Advanced excel skills
Project financing 
Organizational structure
Energy production
Renewable energy basics
Contract reading
I learned how to build a financial model, how project finance works and some of the broader context surrounding renewable energy and finance in general.
Financial analysis and modeling, policy analysis along with renewable energy development
Learned a lot about project finance and the whole business of green energy
Financial modeling for project finance, excel formatting best practices, innovating financing mechanisms for renewable energy

Understanding of full process of developing and financing renewable energy projects

Excel modeling best practices

Legal/contractural requirements of renewable energy projects
Very specific - how to build a finance model in excel

I learned so much about renewable energy projects, from the engineering and mechanics of wind turbines to global energy markets to the financial models and legal contracts that structure them. The coursework alternates between reading legal contracts and learning to build financial models in Excel. The lectures also touch on energy policy and current events in renewable energy.
Financial modeling, reneewable energy development
Creating spreadsheets for professional usage, clean energy-related concepts and any financial dimension
Financial modelling in Excel, basics of solar and wind energy, reading contract and agreements, findings best scenarios and funding schemes for energy projects in developing countries

I went from having no knowledge of project finance to being able to build financial models and read and understand dense contracts. My comfort with using Excel has increased greatly.  
Overall, the learnings and skills I got from this class can translate to many fields, and I learned a lot about renewable energy overall. It is a great class.
Business strategy, accounting, financial modelling, strategic thinking, renewable energy systems, contract law, etc. etc. etc.
Financial modelling. Excel, forecasting
Learned tips on excel model building and a lot more about how project finance works.
How the renewable energy marker for developers work in the US
A lot about financial modelling and many different aspects of project finance in both solar and wind technologies, along with the law, regulations, incentives and need for renewables.
Probably the best course in Yale to learn financial modeling skills on Excel.
I learned how to create a financial model from scratch and learned so much about the energy sector and Excel in general.
I gained insight into the complicated world of renewable energy project finance contracts, deal structures and financial modeling.
Excel, energy markets, financial modeling,
I learned about corporate financial structures, contracts, and tax incentives that influence the way companies are designed and operated.
Projet finance
Excel skills, Financial Modelling skills, resilience, ability to work under pressure
Very well.
I should have put even more time on this class because I was unfamiliar to most of the concepts, and I believe I didn't learn nor understood everything that was taught
The knowledge and skills which I gained in this course aligned very well with my expectations.
Met all of my expectations
Exceeded all (very high) expectations
EVERYTHING IS MET

I learned a ton in this course. As someone without a business background, I felt challenged throughout and enjoyed working on the assignments (even when they were over my head). Generally, the assignments were well designed to be challenging but possible.
Beyond expectations
Extremely well
I learned much more than I expected before this class.
Very well
Insights went beyond my expectations, purely because of the breadth and depth of what I learned. I knew I would learn a lot, but I didn't think I would go so deep into everything.

The modeling was what I expected, and the contextual part and legal document interpretation skills I didn't quite know to expect, so I got what I was looking for and more. Although the course material was very wide-ranging and varied, it all flowed very naturally.
Very well!
Very much! one of the best classes at Yale

Expectations were surpassed--though challenging for someone who did not have any experience in finance prior to the course, this is one of the best classes I've ever taken that taught me real-world skills that I will likely use in my future career
My expectations were vastly exceeded.
Very well aligned.
I had very high expectations for the class, because so many of my classmate had hyped it up, and the class certainly met those expectations.
Exactly as I had expected
I was able to gain essential Excel skills to perform any project finance analysis. The class met my expectation in gaining those skills.
Very good
They went above and beyond! This class was wonderful.
Very well. The course is very challenging, but you get what you put into it.

The knowledge, skills, and insights gained exceeded my expectations. The learning and skills from this course directly relate to real world scenarios and applications. I will be able the use the insights and information well into my career.
Very well. Everything was new to me from the onset. I ended up with a lot of new skills.
The course was a lot more focused on the legal aspect of things than I expected (and would have wanted)

I expected more. If you have worked in Project Finance the class will be interesting and useful, however you will not learn a lot. If you want to work in the US totally recommended, if not, probably just audit it

For someone with almost no background in Finance, this class offered a lot more than expected. I was expecting to understand the tits and bits of finance and how banks and other financial institutions make decision about what projects are financeworthy and which ones are not and this class provided me with that knowledge pretty well.
Exact match,
Very well!

The class aligned well with my expectations and was a really tremendous overview of many important topics. The material was presented in a really interesting way and I learned many things that I had no exposure to beforehand.
Amazing!
I heard this was a great class, it was a great class.
Very well
They aligned very well with my expectations

There should definitely be a warning and additional study material for students without financial background, as it is basically a whole new language and the class moves extremely fast and you can fall behind already in the first lesson.

There is an endless amount of resources given to us in this class in order to be successful.  There is a perfect mix of knowledge and skill building. Everything in the class connects well to the goal of the course and builds on itself logically.

Assignments are a lot of work and take a lot of time, but all serve a purpose in our learning.

Strength: the lectures, alternating types of homework each week, the TAs, the network of people you meet
Weakness: the Sunday deadline was difficult for senior undergrads, the TA office hours were inconvenient (at the same time as my classes)

Strengths: amazing instruction, well organized, expectations clear, strong feedback on assignments

Weaknesses: 3-hour lecture once a week is just not an ideal format. Professor Gross certainly made the best of it, but it's impossible not to lose some focus and take away less in the latter parts of each lecture.
More modelling would be great. i was not a big fan of reading legal texts

Again, the assignments and some of the lectures on financial topics were very helpful. I do not intend to use Excel as a daily tool at my job but it was a great way to learn the material and how project finance concepts work in real life. I think Professor Gross was effective at conveying how practitioners might use these skills and how they might be further complicated in practice. Also, the TFs were generally very helpful.

I was personally not a fan of some of the more TED Talk style lectures. It all felt a little silly. As someone who is actually interested in the save the world side of the class (that is, I did not join just to bolster my modeling experience), some of those rah-rah moments were seriously cringe-worthy. Maybe they were just meant as mental breaks from the harder material. But there has to be a better way.

Strength: Well structures, excellent professor, excellent TA support, video-recorded sessions, excellent feedback on assignments, best course which I took at Yale.


Weakness: none.
Covered a wide range of materials and I am sure this is a great way to prepare people if they want to work in finance.

Strengths: 
- Making us figure out how to do things in Excel
- Really made us get into the grit and do the work

Weaknesses:
- TF availability for the final assignment was tough, but I understand why

Strengths: Engaging lectures with real-world examples and a very practical skillset. The recitations were extremely helpful too.
Weaknesses: It's probably more manageable with a smaller class because office hours could get crazy and there is not as much opportunity for one-on-one catching up on the material. Also, I imagine the TAs would have left more detailed comments on HW if they hadn't had as many assignments to grade.
Some assignments were a bit long and should be split into two! Otherwise, I thought the course was really well thought out and beneficial.

To much work, be prepared to work hard.
It is tricky to keep up with everything, make sure to attend recitation sessions
Amazing class with a passionate professor
You are in for a treat
Hard to speak of any weaknesses and countless strengths. Hard to work with TFs on final project since hours were limited to one TF at a time who had to answer multiple questions from many students
Dan Gross is an incredible teacher. The lectures were very well organized, real-world examples were woven into the material, assignments were challenging and effective learning tools.
You benefit from a tangible outcome project finance model. The lectures can be dry and pedantic. A lot of the learning happens independently. The TA staff was stellar.

The course is incredibly effective at building skills from zero to 100. Most students enter the class with barely any understanding of financial modeling, and they come away with the ability to build a complex financial model. A weakness of the course is the format itself - it is difficult to maintain attention spans for 3 hour lectures. At times, the lectures felt like they were all over the place - the timing and logic of when we are taught certain concepts could be improved.
Amazing course overall, I wish we didn't have a group project though
The class is very well organized and has many resources. It could improve by having shorter lecture time and more optional readings or lecture slides
Very good timing and everything that's important in the real world is covered. In class, demos were very helpful and there should be more of them especially in the third part of the course.

The strengths is that the high level of engagement and challenging assignments force you to actually learn and get comfortable with building financial models and synthesizing difficult contracts. I am not sure I would call this a weakness, but the course is extremely challenging and the playing field is not level as some people are very familiar with financial modeling.
The pedagogy of this course was exceptional. The learning is intense but well worth it.
Too much work. The weekly assignments took the whole weekend!

Strengths: Uses real-life case and walks you through it. 
Weaknesses: Not sure I could replicate what I did in the end plus I spent a lot of time reading legal documents that were way too long and complicated so didn't take much from them.
The TAs are very knowledgeable but only now what they have seen in class for the most part so they don't really understand really well outside of that

Strengths: Dan Gross himself and the way the whole class has been designed with focus on both the modelling and the project documents. The use of all that we had learned over the semester on the final model was very helpful too.

Weakness: The recitation sessions could have been improved and the TAs could have been more flexible with identifying the best practices of modelling. Because I dont think there can just be one template of best practices across the whole industry.
you harvest what you sow

It is very clear that Dan Gross has put in a huge amount of time and consideration to make the class as useful as possible for students who are coming from different backgrounds and will go on to work in different aspects of the clean energy space. It was great to have the chance to dive deep into both the contracts side of project finance and the financial modeling to get a good sense of how the work is done overall. I also really enjoyed the latter parts of the class where we applied project finance tools to other issues beyond just renewable energy. I think one thing to improve might be the recitations. There were some big discrepancies in terms of quality of those presentations among the TAs, and sometimes it seemed like a lot of time put in for not much gained.

Keep Dan Gross as the lecturer. Continue to keep a high number of TA's 
Make the recordings available for permanent download.

The weakness of the course (no fault to Professor Gross) is that there are so many people at different skill levels, it becomes challenging to stay engaging to those who have prior knowledge of excel or the technical details. Strength of the class is that Dan is constantly modifying it to make sure people are learning what they need to learn.

1. Students need more preparation before the first assignment. While learning on our own is valuable under many circumstances, in this case we would have learned more with a bit of additional help and guidance.
2. The delays in posting recitation videos created a real challenge for students unable to attend some of the recitations in person. If SOM IT will not post them quickly, an alternative site for recitations (FES) should be used in the future.
3. The basic final model should include periodicity. It would still be considerably easier than the advanced model, but ensure that all students finish the course with a fuller understanding. The enhanced model was too long. Pairing back a few of the less important options would allow students to focus on the more critical advanced skills without reducing the amount they learn in the process.
Well structured and organized. The fast pace and heavy material content made it hard to keep up with the class. I was unable to digest learnings from one section before we were on to the next.
It's very hard!!! If you don't have a background in finance, definitely make up your mind that you will need extra time to understand the concepts.

I would tell a student considering taking this class that it will take a lot more time than most other courses.  I would suggest starting assignments as early as possible and going to recitation sessions and office hours.

I took this as a senior undergraduate and got a lot out of it, definitely take it! The Sunday deadlines are difficult if you don't start the assignments early in the week because for seniors, lots of events start happening Sunday nights in the spring semester, so if you have the opportunity to take it as a junior, then do that. The TAs are willing to help, Dan is a fantastic lecturer, and the assignments are really interesting if you want to know more about how to actually make a wind project happen. In this class, I learned way more about the mechanics behind wind than in any other undergraduate class, who's scope on renewable energy is either an introductory EVST class or an advanced Electrical Engineering class. It's really fun to learn the skill of financial modeling because it's useful for life and any energy or finance related job.
Take it. It really is as good as everyone says. Also the skills are transferrable far beyond the confines of renewable energy, could be applied to project finance in many industries.
Best modeling class

This course requires putting in a number of hours every week. The assignments are also truly cumulative and so if you fall behind (or even if you just mess up) it can be very tough to catch up. The amount of time was not totally stable from week-to-week but I spent anywhere from 5 to 25 hours working on my assignments. That being said, I strongly recommend the course if you feel that you can manage it.

This is an all round course in project finance and renewable energy. Be prepared for the grueling home assignments. But learning is immense and at the end of the course you can look back with great satisfaction. The model developed during the course is a takeaway which can be straighaway applied in practical settings.
Be ready to spend 10 hours every week on completing the assignment;
Attend class and recitations. They are very helpful for you to understand concepts and finish assignments.
Go to office hours! TFs are great for explaining in detail concepts gone over in class

This class has been taught for years, so you know the material and syllabus have been refined. Make sure you are willing to commit to attending recitations in addition to lectures (It's always better to be there in person because there may be issues with the recording technology) to maximize your understanding.  At the beginning, the homework may be overwhelming, but it only helps prepare you for future assignments.
Might be useful take an accounting course before or at the same time. Still manageable without prior finance experience but it may be harder to grasp concepts immediately.
Even if you don't think you like finance, this class is extremely valuable in understanding how renewable energy projects get built.
Take this course if you want to learn how to build a project finance model. Don't overestimate what else you will learn.
I would take the course only if you are prepared to put in the time and energy to get a lot out of it. It is challenging but rewarding.

Definitely take this class  Dan is not just one of the best teachers at Yale, but also shares valuable life lessons/anecdotes in his classes to keep them engaging. Even if you're tangentially interested in renewable energy, this class will teach you useful concepts about financial modeling.
I highly recommend this class if anyone wants to learn Excel, in combination with energy concepts.
It is really really hard but worth the effort! Start working on assignments early.
Make sure you don't have a heavy course load otherwise so you can commit a lot of time to this course, and thus maximize the benefit from it.
If you are at all interested in business, finance, project development, or renewable energy take this course. It can be a lot of work but it is well worth it! Dan Gross is an exceptional teacher.
Highly recommended.
Make sure you are ok with reading a lot of legal documents as well as doing a lot of excel modeling.
Do the basic final model unless you want to work in the US. The TAs will not give you the appropriate help as they sometimes didn't agree on many things and it's just unnecessary stress
Be ready spend 3-4 hours everyweek if you already quite competent in excel and familiar to financial concepts like NPV, interest and tax. 6-7 if you are new to these subjects.
Be prepared to learn a lot and put in lots of time and effort -- but it will pay off if you do.
Make time for the course, you will learn how the world works!
The course enables you to learn a clear, useful skillset. It is a heavy workload, particularly if you don't have experience in financial modeling in excel, so be prepared.
Take it if you need the skills but be prepared to dedicate a great amount of time to it! If it's not aligned with your personal and career goals don't enrol. Passion helps to deal with the pressure
